Revenue results, QoQ changes, YoY change.summary: In 2024 Q2, Intel reported a revenue of $12.83 billion, marking a 1% sequential increase from the previous quarter and a 1% year-over-year decrease. This revenue was in line with the guidance provided in May. The revenue changes were influenced by an export license restriction affecting the client business in China, while Intel Products and Intel Foundry saw 4% year-over-year growth, offsetting declines in cyclical business areas. Management attributed revenue deviations to slower-than-expected recovery, modest inventory digestion in the Client Computing Group, and underperformance in the Data Center and AI sectors. They expect gradual sequential revenue growth through the remainder of the year, with normal seasonal growth anticipated in Q4.

report.question: What are the key revenue figures for 2024 Q2, and how do they compare QoQ and YoY?
retrieved: We have entered Q3 with a very clear focus and renewed intensity to up our gain and are motivated by the progress we are seeing as we execute our strategy and realize our vision. That is the mindset driving us forward as we continue to build a stronger Intel. With that, I'll pass it over to Dave.\nDavid Zinsner: Thank you, Pat, and good afternoon, everyone. Second quarter revenue was $12.8 billion, down 1 point year-over-year and up 1% sequentially. Revenue was in line with the range we provided in May after receiving notice of an export license restriction, which negatively impacted our client business in China. Intel Products and Intel Foundry both delivered 4% year-over-year growth, offset by headwinds in our more cyclical businesses. Profitability was significantly more challenged versus our previous expectations with Q2 gross margin of 38.7% and EPS of $0.02. Weaker than expected gross margin was due to three main drivers. The largest impact was caused by an accelerated ramp of

the second half as demand for traditional servers improves modestly. Revenue for the NEX business was approximately flat both sequentially and year-over-year, so excluding the previously discussed inventory digestion impacting the telco market, NEX delivered 10% year-over-year growth in the first half. Q2 operating profit for Intel Products was $2.9 billion, 25% of revenue and up approximately $400 million year-over-year, on higher revenue and reduced inventory reserves. Intel Foundry delivered revenue of $4.3 billion, down 1 point sequentially and up 4% year-over-year, driven by increased wafer volume on Intel 7 and our first EUV nodes, Intel 4 and Intel 3. Foundry Services revenue more than doubled sequentially off a small base, including the start of advanced packaging revenue. Foundry operating loss of $2.8 billion was worse sequentially. We expect operating losses to continue at approximately the same rate in Q3 with more than 85% of wafer volumes still coming from pre-EUV nodes

customers to reduce inventory over the second half of the year, along with the continued modest negative impact from export controls. These market dynamics should result in below seasonal revenue growth in Q3 with the client business flat to down and modest growth in data center and edge markets. With an expectation of healthier inventory positions exiting the quarter and the continuation of an enterprise refresh cycle, we should see revenue growth at the high end of seasonal in the fourth quarter. We expect gross margins to be moderately weaker sequentially with modest revenue growth and efficiencies offset by a continued ramp of new manufacturing nodes. While we will continue our work to improve near-term profitability, a heavier dependence on external wafers as we ramp AI PC products over the next several quarters will pressure gross margins. As a result of these factors, we expect revenue of $12.5 billion to $13.5 billion in the third quarter. At the midpoint of $13 billion, we
report.init_answer: For 2024 Q2, Intel reported a revenue of $12.83 billion. This represents a 1% increase sequentially (quarter-over-quarter, QoQ) from the previous quarter and a 1% decrease year-over-year (YoY) compared to the same quarter in the previous year.

report.init_answer: The changes in Intel's Q2 revenue were influenced by several factors. The revenue for the quarter was $12.8 billion, showing a 1% sequential increase but a 1% decrease year-over-year. This revenue was in line with the guidance provided in May. A significant factor affecting revenue was an export license restriction that negatively impacted Intel's client business in China. Despite this challenge, Intel Products and Intel Foundry experienced 4% year-over-year growth, which helped offset the revenue decline in more cyclical business areas. Overall, the revenue performance aligned with previous guidance, as Intel anticipated the impact of the export restriction and other market conditions.

and liquidity needed to support our long-term strategy. We remain confident that we have and will continue to make the investments needed to drive long-term shareholder value and we view cost discipline as the compass that drives effective execution, helping teams stay on track to both prioritize and achieve measurable results. The operational and capital improvements we are driving will be especially important as we manage the business through the near term. While we expect to deliver sequential revenue growth through the rest of the year, the pace of the recovery will be slower than expected, which is reflected in our Q3 outlook. Specifically, Q3 will be impacted by a modest inventory digestion in CCG with DCAI and our more cyclical businesses of NEX, Altera, and Mobileye trending below our original forecast. Our outlook reflects industry-wide conditions without any meaningful change in our market share expectations. As we look into Q4, normal seasonal revenue growth has
report.init_answer: Management explained that the revenue deviations are primarily due to a slower-than-expected recovery pace, impacted by modest inventory digestion in the Client Computing Group (CCG) and underperformance in the Data Center and AI (DCAI) sectors, as well as the more cyclical businesses of Network and Edge (NEX), Altera, and Mobileye. These areas are trending below their original forecasts. For future expectations, management anticipates sequential revenue growth through the rest of the year, although the recovery will be gradual. In Q4, they expect normal seasonal revenue growth, without any significant changes in market share expectations.

wafer sales and the breakdown to wafer q.summary: In 2024 Q2, there is no specific numerical data on wafer sales volume. However, there is an increase in wafer ASP due to a shift towards advanced technology nodes, specifically EUV wafers, which have better margins. This ASP improvement is driven by advancements in technology and increased demand for advanced packaging, enhancing pricing dynamics.

report.question: How has the wafer ASP changed, and what are the underlying reasons for the variation?
retrieved: more leading-edge wafers, the margins on those wafers are significantly better than the margins in pre-EUV nodes. So that will -- that will be one factor that will certainly help us. It also -- in that regard, that also helps us on the pricing side because, obviously, from a wafer perspective, we get better pricing on EUV wafers as opposed to pre-EUV wafers. And then ultimately, I think on pricing, it will really come down to when we have a competitive process and we have competitive products running on a competitive process and we're delivering what the customers want, that helps us in terms of the pricing dynamic. And we're getting to the place as Pat talked about where we're starting to deliver on all those fronts. there, the capital requirements are not as significant as required for wafer capacity. So we believe very much that we're seeing a surge of interest there. Customers in advanced packaging are clearly interested in us for capacity, but increasingly for our most advanced packaging technology. So that's an area that we believe we have as, and we've described before, as the on-ramp for Intel Foundry and that's continuing to look very good. The final point is the Intel Foundry capacity will be aligned with, right, to the first order, the Intel product requirements. And clearly, there's a lot of tiles externally in 2025, we bring those home in 2026, that's when we'll start to really, as Dave said, see the benefits of the model that we've put in place. report.init_answer: The wafer ASP (Average Selling Price) has increased due to a shift towards more advanced technology nodes, specifically EUV (Extreme Ultraviolet) wafers. The transcript indicates that EUV wafers have significantly better margins compared to pre-EUV nodes, which implies higher pricing. The improvement in wafer ASP is attributed to competitive process advancements, delivering what customers want, and increased demand for advanced packaging technology. These factors enhance the pricing dynamic, allowing for better ASPs as Intel progresses through the next few years.

report.init_answer: The transcript indicates a mixed trend in wafer demand across different customer segments. The client business is expected to be flat to down, reflecting potentially weaker demand or inventory adjustments in this segment. In contrast, there is modest growth anticipated in the data center and edge markets, suggesting a relatively healthier demand in these areas. Additionally, there is a surge of interest in advanced packaging and more advanced wafer technology, such as EUV wafers, which offer better margins and pricing dynamics. This indicates a shift towards more technologically advanced and potentially higher-value wafer products, driven by customer interest in advanced packaging technology and the ongoing enterprise refresh cycle. Overall, while some segments face challenges, there is strong interest and demand for advanced wafer technologies in others.

sales by segment or platforms, their res.summary:
The provided information does not specify exact sales figures or detailed margin levels for different segments or platforms in 2024 Q2. However, Intel Products and Intel Foundry both delivered 4% year-over-year growth, and Altera reported $361 million in revenue, up 6% sequentially. The gross margin for the quarter was approximately 35.43%, with an expectation of 38% in Q3. Management highlighted Intel's strong position in the commercial market, particularly in AI PCs, and expressed confidence in their market position with upcoming products. They noted better performance in the enterprise market compared to the cloud market and are focused on improving efficiency and restructuring to enhance competitiveness.

Explanation: The summary consolidates available data on sales growth for Intel Products, Intel Foundry, and Altera, while noting the absence of specific segment figures. It mentions the overall gross margin and future expectations, along with management's strategic focus and market insights, providing a cohesive response aligned with the key aspect.

However, difficult conditions in China, which are impacting many Western automotive suppliers, led Mobileye to lower their revenue and income guidance for the second half. Altera delivered revenue of $361 million, up 6% sequentially with operating margins improving 4 points in the quarter. Revenue remains below consumption as inventory positions tied to previous supply constraints are worked down. We expect double-digit sequential revenue growth through the second half as customers return to more normal buying patterns. Now turning to our Q3 guidance. Weaker spending across consumer and enterprise markets, especially in China, and continued focus on AI server investments in the cloud have reduced our TAM expectations for 2024. As a result, customer inventory levels are elevated. We expect customers to reduce inventory over the second half of the year, along with the continued modest negative impact from export controls. These market dynamics should result in below seasonal revenue

not using our EDA vendors as effectively. We've done too many steppings. We validate versus build-in design quality. We also realized that as an IDM 1.0, we were never built for efficiency. We were built for leadership. And now as we add this focus on efficiency, we see a lot of opportunities. I'm having each of the four business areas, client, networking, and data center, look at their own portfolios, even though those are the right product areas for us for the future, and similarly, the portfolio of our Intel Foundry business and that's the work that we've now been undertaking and we're now accelerating based on the less than expected quarterly results, we're accelerating those impacts. We're going to drive that in the second half of this year. We want to get these restructurings done quickly so that we can move forward more aggressively with the
report.init_answer: Management provided insights about their strong position in the commercial market, particularly with their vPro assets, which have been successful for customers, especially during the CrowdStrike Blue Screen period. They emphasized their leadership in AI PC and expressed confidence in their market position, which is expected to strengthen further with upcoming products like Lunar Lake and Panther Lake. Additionally, they noted that the enterprise market is more favorable for them compared to the cloud market, and they see early indications of a positive cycle in the enterprise segment. Management is also focused on improving efficiency and restructuring to enhance their competitive stance.

sales guidance, forecast, or trend by se.summary: Intel's sales guidance for Q3 2024 anticipates overall revenue between $12.5 billion and $13.5 billion, with the client business expected to be flat to down, and modest growth projected in the data center and edge markets. Historically, Intel faced profitability challenges in Q2 2024, with a net income loss and negative operating income, indicating ongoing pressures. The forecast suggests a slower-than-expected recovery, influenced by inventory digestion and below-forecast performance in several segments. Key drivers for future sales include strategic restructuring and growth in advanced packaging, while risks involve market competition and inventory dynamics.

We expect gross margins to be moderately weaker sequentially with modest revenue growth and efficiencies offset by a continued ramp of new manufacturing nodes. While we will continue our work to improve near-term profitability, a heavier dependence on external wafers as we ramp AI PC products over the next several quarters will pressure gross margins. Based on the earnings call transcript, Intel's sales guidance for the upcoming third quarter is as follows:

- Overall revenue is expected to be between $12.5 billion and $13.5 billion, with a midpoint of $13 billion.
- The client business is expected to be flat to down.
- Modest growth is anticipated in the data center and edge markets.

report.init_answer:
The forecasted trends indicate a slower-than-expected recovery in revenue growth through the rest of the year, as mentioned in the earnings call transcript. Specifically, the company expects sequential revenue growth, but the pace will be slower than initially anticipated, with Q3 impacted by modest inventory digestion in the Client Computing Group (CCG) and below-forecast performance in the Data Center and AI (DCAI), Network and Edge (NEX), Altera, and Mobileye segments.

Historically, as per the provided financial data for Q2 2024, Intel reported a net income loss of $1.61 billion, with a negative net income ratio of -12.55%. The operating income was also negative at -$1.021 billion, indicating challenges in profitability. The gross profit margin stood at 35.43%, reflecting pressure on cost management and operational efficiency.

Comparatively, the forecast suggests continued challenges with inventory and cyclical business segments, which are affecting near-term performance. However, the company remains focused on cost discipline and long-term investments to drive shareholder value. This indicates a strategic shift towards managing current operational hurdles while positioning for future growth, albeit at a slower recovery pace than previously expected.

report.question: What are the key drivers or risks influencing future sales expectations?

We want to get these restructurings done quickly so that we can move forward more aggressively with the product lines next year. In terms of the long-term forecast, we're clearly tempering our view of how fast we can grow in the near-term based on the market conditions. But our model is built that we will scale up or scale down the capital requirements appropriate to the market conditions we see. We believe the long-term guidance that we've given you, the 60:40, getting to the Foundry business model we've described, the growth areas that we've said, those are larger portions of our business. We believe those are long-term still achievable in that regard and we're on track for many of those things in the models that we're laying out and today's actions will help accelerate us achieving those.\nJohn Pitzer: Ross, do you have a quick follow-up?\nRoss Seymore: Yes, I do. report.init_answer:
The key drivers influencing future sales expectations include the company's strategic focus on restructuring to accelerate product line development, as mentioned in the earnings call. This restructuring aims to position the company more aggressively for growth in the coming year. Additionally, the company's long-term guidance and business model, particularly the transition to a Foundry business model and growth in packaging, are expected to be significant drivers of future sales.

On the risk side, market conditions have led the company to temper its near-term growth expectations. There is also the potential impact of competition in the client space, particularly from ARM's entry into the market, which could modestly affect sales. Furthermore, inventory dynamics with OEMs and broader market conditions could pose risks to achieving the guided sales expectations.
